title: Valentine’s single-page Yes/No interaction with escalating Yes button and celebratory modal

requirements.summary: Build a responsive single-page homepage showing the exact Valentine question with “Yes” and “No” buttons.
acceptanceCriteria: On initial load, the homepage shows the question text exactly as provided.
Two clearly labeled buttons are present: “Yes” and “No”.
The page is usable on both mobile and desktop screen sizes (responsive layout).

file_operations.description: Create the single-page homepage UI rendering the exact question text “annammooo will you be my valentine” and two buttons labeled “Yes” and “No”, laid out responsively for mobile/desktop.

requirements.summary: Implement escalating interaction: “No” shows a try-again message and progressively enlarges “Yes” until “No” becomes effectively hidden; reset on refresh.
acceptanceCriteria: Clicking “No” displays an error/try-again message in English (e.g., “Oops—try again.”).
Each consecutive “No” click increases the “Yes” button size relative to its previous size.
The “Yes” button continues to grow with each “No” click without breaking layout (no overflow that makes the page unusable).
After enough “No” clicks, the “No” button is no longer practically clickable/visible because it is covered/hidden by the enlarged “Yes” button.
Refreshing the page resets the interaction back to the initial state (initial button sizes, no error message shown).

file_operations.description: Add client-side interaction state (e.g., no-click count, error message visibility) and compute progressive “Yes” button scaling/prominence per “No” click; ensure layout stays usable while “Yes” grows and eventually overlays/covers “No” via stacking/positioning so “No” becomes effectively unclickable; rely on in-memory state so refresh resets.

requirements.summary: Show a dismissible modal on “Yes” click containing a custom static image and the exact provided note text with line break.
acceptanceCriteria: Clicking “Yes” opens a modal overlay on top of the homepage content.
The modal displays the provided message text exactly (including punctuation and line break between the two sentences/lines).
The modal displays the custom image (from static assets) above or alongside the message.
The modal can be dismissed via a close button and by pressing Escape and/or clicking outside the modal (at least one dismissal method must exist).
After dismissing the modal, the user can still see the homepage state (it does not crash or navigate away unintentionally).

file_operations.description: Create a lightweight accessible modal component that supports open/close, renders the static image from frontend/public/assets/generated/valentine-popup-illustration.dim_1024x1024.png, shows the exact note text including the required line break, and supports dismissal via a close button plus Escape and/or backdrop click.
Wire the “Yes” button to open ValentineModal and pass in the exact message text; ensure closing the modal restores the underlying homepage view without navigation.

requirements.summary: Apply a cohesive Valentine-themed visual design (warm reds/pinks/creams) consistently across the homepage, buttons, error message, and modal; avoid a blue/purple primary palette.
acceptanceCriteria: The UI uses a consistent Valentine-appropriate theme (e.g., warm reds/pinks/creams, playful typography) across all elements.
Buttons, modal, and text share a consistent style system (sizes, radii, shadows, spacing).
The primary visual palette is not blue/purple.

file_operations.description: Define global Valentine-themed styling (warm reds/pinks/creams, consistent radii/shadows/spacing) using existing global styling entry point so the theme applies across homepage, buttons, error message, and modal; avoid any blue/purple primary palette.
Apply consistent themed classes/styles to the homepage layout, buttons, and error/try-again message to match the Valentine design system defined in frontend/src/index.css.
Style the modal (overlay, card, typography, spacing, close control) to match the same Valentine theme and maintain responsive behavior.

requirements.summary: Add the required generated image under frontend/public/assets/generated/ and reference it directly from the UI (no backend involvement).
acceptanceCriteria: At least one generated image file exists under `frontend/public/assets/generated/` with the exact filename specified in the image requirements.
The modal’s image is loaded via a static URL path (e.g., `/assets/generated/...`) and renders correctly in production build.
No backend endpoints are added to fetch or transform the image.

file_operations.description: Add the generated static image asset file exactly at frontend/public/assets/generated/valentine-popup-illustration.dim_1024x1024.png for use in the celebratory modal.

Reference and render the static image from frontend/public/assets/generated/valentine-popup-illustration.dim_1024x1024.png via a direct static asset path so it works in production builds, without any backend fetching.
